House File 2087 - Introduced


                                 HOUSE FILE 

                                 HOUSE FILE 
                                 HOUSE FILE                                  HOUSE FILE                                  BY  HUNTER

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act relating to the creation of the medical cannabis Act and
  2    providing for criminal penalties and fees.
  3 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 5420YH (4) 86
    rh/rj

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.  Section 124.401, subsection 5, unnumbered
  1  2 paragraph 3, Code 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.  Section 124.401, subsection 5, unnumbered
  1  2 paragraph 3, Code 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer 

  1  1    Section 1.  Section 124.401, subsection 5, unnumbered
  1  2 paragraph 3, Code 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer 
  1  1    Section 1.  Section 124.401, subsection 5, unnumbered
  1  2 paragraph 3, Code 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer   1  1    Section 1.  Section 124.401, subsection 5, unnumbered
  1  2 paragraph 3, Code 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer   1  2 paragraph 3, Code 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer   1  3    A person may knowingly or intentionally recommend, possess,
  1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer   1  4 use, dispense, deliver, transport, or administer   1  5   1  6 delivery, transporting, or administering is in accordance with
  1  7 the provisions of chapter   1  7 the provisions of chapter   1  8 paragraph,   1  9 section   1 10    Sec. 2.    1 11    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Medical
  1 12 Cannabis Act".
  1 13    Sec. 3.    1 12 Cannabis Act".
  1 13    Sec. 3.    1 13    Sec. 3.    1 14    The purpose of this chapter is to allow for the medical use
  1 15 of cannabis in a regulated program for alleviating symptoms
  1 16 caused by debilitating medical conditions and the medical
  1 17 treatments for such conditions.
  1 18    Sec. 4.    1 15 of cannabis in a regulated program for alleviating symptoms
  1 16 caused by debilitating medical conditions and the medical
  1 17 treatments for such conditions.
  1 18    Sec. 4.    1 16 caused by debilitating medical conditions and the medical
  1 17 treatments for such conditions.
  1 18    Sec. 4.    1 17 treatments for such conditions.
  1 18    Sec. 4.    1 18    Sec. 4.    1 19    As used in this chapter:
  1 20    1.  "Adequate supply" means an amount of cannabis, in any
  1 21 form approved by the department, possessed by a qualified
  1 22 patient or collectively possessed by a qualified patient and
  1 23 the qualified patient's primary caregiver that is determined
  1 24 by department rule to be no more than reasonably necessary to
  1 25 ensure the uninterrupted availability of cannabis for a period
  1 26 of three months and that is derived solely from an intrastate
  1 27 source.
  1 28    2.  "Cannabis" means all parts of the plants of the genus
  1 29 cannabis, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin
  1 30 extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound,
  1 31 manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the
  1 32 plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinols.
  1 33 "Cannabis" does not include the mature stalks of the plant;
  1 34 fiber produced from the stalks; oil or cake made from the
  1 35 seeds of the plant; any other compound, manufacture, salt,
  2  1 derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks,
  2  2 except the resin extracted therefrom; fiber; or oil or cake
  2  3 or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of
  2  4 germination.
  2  5    3.  "Debilitating medical condition" means any of the
  2  6 following:
  2  7    a.  Cancer.
  2  8    b.  Glaucoma.
  2  9    c.  Multiple sclerosis.
  2 10    d.  Epilepsy.
  2 11    e.  AIDS or HIV as defined in section 141A.1.
  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.
  2 34    8.  a.  "Primary caregiver" means a resident of this state,
  2 35 at least eighteen years of age, who has been designated by
  3  1 the qualified patient's practitioner or a person having legal
  3  2 custody of the qualified patient, as being necessary to take
  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    1 20    1.  "Adequate supply" means an amount of cannabis, in any
  1 21 form approved by the department, possessed by a qualified
  1 22 patient or collectively possessed by a qualified patient and
  1 23 the qualified patient's primary caregiver that is determined
  1 24 by department rule to be no more than reasonably necessary to
  1 25 ensure the uninterrupted availability of cannabis for a period
  1 26 of three months and that is derived solely from an intrastate
  1 27 source.
  1 28    2.  "Cannabis" means all parts of the plants of the genus
  1 29 cannabis, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin
  1 30 extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound,
  1 31 manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the
  1 32 plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinols.
  1 33 "Cannabis" does not include the mature stalks of the plant;
  1 34 fiber produced from the stalks; oil or cake made from the
  1 35 seeds of the plant; any other compound, manufacture, salt,
  2  1 derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks,
  2  2 except the resin extracted therefrom; fiber; or oil or cake
  2  3 or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of
  2  4 germination.
  2  5    3.  "Debilitating medical condition" means any of the
  2  6 following:
  2  7    a.  Cancer.
  2  8    b.  Glaucoma.
  2  9    c.  Multiple sclerosis.
  2 10    d.  Epilepsy.
  2 11    e.  AIDS or HIV as defined in section 141A.1.
  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.
  2 34    8.  a.  "Primary caregiver" means a resident of this state,
  2 35 at least eighteen years of age, who has been designated by
  3  1 the qualified patient's practitioner or a person having legal
  3  2 custody of the qualified patient, as being necessary to take
  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    1 21 form approved by the department, possessed by a qualified
  1 22 patient or collectively possessed by a qualified patient and
  1 23 the qualified patient's primary caregiver that is determined
  1 24 by department rule to be no more than reasonably necessary to
  1 25 ensure the uninterrupted availability of cannabis for a period
  1 26 of three months and that is derived solely from an intrastate
  1 27 source.

  2  2 except the resin extracted therefrom; fiber; or oil or cake

  2  4 germination.

  2  6 following:
  2  7    a.  Cancer.
  2  8    b.  Glaucoma.
  2  9    c.  Multiple sclerosis.
  2 10    d.  Epilepsy.
  2 11    e.  AIDS or HIV as defined in section 141A.1.
  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.

  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.

  1 30 extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound,
  1 31 manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the
  1 32 plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinols.
  1 33 "Cannabis" does not include the mature stalks of the plant;
  1 34 fiber produced from the stalks; oil or cake made from the
  1 35 seeds of the plant; any other compound, manufacture, salt,
  2  1 derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks,
  2  2 except the resin extracted therefrom; fiber; or oil or cake
  2  3 or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of
  2  4 germination.
  2  5    3.  "Debilitating medical condition" means any of the
  2  6 following:
  2  7    a.  Cancer.
  2  8    b.  Glaucoma.
  2  9    c.  Multiple sclerosis.
  2 10    d.  Epilepsy.
  2 11    e.  AIDS or HIV as defined in section 141A.1.
  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.
  2 34    8.  a.  "Primary caregiver" means a resident of this state,
  2 35 at least eighteen years of age, who has been designated by
  3  1 the qualified patient's practitioner or a person having legal
  3  2 custody of the qualified patient, as being necessary to take
  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.

  1 26 of three months and that is derived solely from an intrastate
  1 27 source.

  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.
  2 34    8.  a.  "Primary caregiver" means a resident of this state,
  2 35 at least eighteen years of age, who has been designated by
  3  1 the qualified patient's practitioner or a person having legal
  3  2 custody of the qualified patient, as being necessary to take
  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    1 32 plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinols.
  1 33 "Cannabis" does not include the mature stalks of the plant;
  1 34 fiber produced from the stalks; oil or cake made from the
  1 35 seeds of the plant; any other compound, manufacture, salt,
  2  1 derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks,
  2  2 except the resin extracted therefrom; fiber; or oil or cake
  2  3 or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of
  2  4 germination.
  2  5    3.  "Debilitating medical condition" means any of the
  2  6 following:
  2  7    a.  Cancer.
  2  8    b.  Glaucoma.
  2  9    c.  Multiple sclerosis.
  2 10    d.  Epilepsy.
  2 11    e.  AIDS or HIV as defined in section 141A.1.
  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.

  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms

  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.
  2 34    8.  a.  "Primary caregiver" means a resident of this state,
  2 35 at least eighteen years of age, who has been designated by
  3  1 the qualified patient's practitioner or a person having legal
  3  2 custody of the qualified patient, as being necessary to take
  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    2  5    3.  "Debilitating medical condition" means any of the
  2  6 following:
  2  7    a.  Cancer.
  2  8    b.  Glaucoma.
  2  9    c.  Multiple sclerosis.
  2 10    d.  Epilepsy.
  2 11    e.  AIDS or HIV as defined in section 141A.1.
  2 12    f.  Spinal cord damage with intractable spasticity.
  2 13    g.  Any other medical condition, medical treatment, or
  2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.

  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    2 14 disease approved by the department.
  2 15    4.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  2 16    5.  "Licensed producer" means any qualified patient, primary
  2 17 caregiver, or nonprofit private entity within this state that
  2 18 the department determines to be qualified to process, produce,
  2 19 possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, deliver, and
  2 20 transport cannabis in this state pursuant to this chapter and
  2 21 that is licensed by the department. A qualified patient or
  2 22 primary caregiver licensed as a producer shall produce no more
  2 23 than an adequate supply of cannabis for the qualified patient's
  2 24 personal use only.
  2 25    6.  "Medical use of cannabis" means the acquisition,
  2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.
  2 34    8.  a.  "Primary caregiver" means a resident of this state,
  2 35 at least eighteen years of age, who has been designated by
  3  1 the qualified patient's practitioner or a person having legal
  3  2 custody of the qualified patient, as being necessary to take
  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".

  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.

  3  3 responsibility for managing the well=being of a qualified
  3  4 patient with respect to the medical use of cannabis pursuant
  3  5 to the provisions of this chapter. A qualified patient may
  3  6 designate one or more primary caregivers.
  3  7    b.  "Primary caregiver" includes an employee of a hospice
  3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.
  3 18    11.  "Registry identification card" means a document issued
  3 19 by the department that identifies a person as a registered
  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    2 26 possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, delivery, transfer,
  2 27 or transportation of cannabis or paraphernalia related to the
  2 28 administration of cannabis to treat or alleviate a registered
  2 29 qualified patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms
  2 30 associated with the patient's debilitating medical condition.
  2 31    7.  "Practitioner" means a person licensed in this state to
  2 32 prescribe and administer a controlled substance regulated under
  2 33 chapter 124.

  3 20 qualified patient or registered primary caregiver.
  3 21    12.  "Written certification" means a statement signed by a
  3 22 qualified patient's practitioner that, in the practitioner's
  3 23 professional opinion, the patient has a debilitating medical
  3 24 condition and the practitioner believes that the potential
  3 25 health benefits of the medical use of cannabis would likely
  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    3  8 program, if the employee meets the definition of a primary
  3  9 caregiver under paragraph "a".
  3 10    9.  "Program" means the medical use of cannabis program
  3 11 established and administered by the department pursuant to
  3 12 rule.
  3 13    10.  "Qualified patient" means a resident of this state who
  3 14 has been diagnosed by a practitioner as having a debilitating
  3 15 medical condition and who has received written certification
  3 16 and been issued a registry identification card pursuant to this
  3 17 chapter.

  3 26 outweigh the health risks for the qualified patient.  A written
  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.

  3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    3 27 certification shall expire at the end of one year from the date
  3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    3 28 of issuance.
  3 29    Sec. 5.    3 29    Sec. 5.    3 30 exemption from criminal and civil penalties.
  3 31    1.  A qualified patient who has been issued and who possesses
  3 32 a registry identification card shall not be subject to arrest
  3 33 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of
  3 34 any right or privilege for the medical use of cannabis if the
  3 35 quantity of cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.
  4  1    2.  A qualified patient's primary caregiver shall not be
  4  2 subject to arrest or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty,
  4  3 or the denial of any right or privilege for the medical use of
  4  4 cannabis on behalf of the qualified patient, if the quantity of
  4  5 cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.
  4  6    3.  Subsection 1 does not apply to a qualified patient under
  4  7 the age of eighteen years unless all of the following apply:
  4  8    a.  The qualified patient's practitioner has explained the
  4  9 potential risks and benefits of the medical use of cannabis
  4 10 to the qualified patient and to a parent, guardian, or person
  4 11 having legal custody of the qualified patient.
  4 12    b.  A parent, guardian, or person having legal custody agrees
  4 13 in writing to do all of the following:
  4 14    (1)  Allow the qualified patient's medical use of cannabis.
  4 15    (2)  Serve as the qualified patient's primary caregiver.
  4 16    (3)  Control the dosage and the frequency of the medical use
  4 17 of cannabis by the qualified patient.
  4 18    (4)  Designate one or more primary caregivers for the
  4 19 qualified patient.
  4 20    4.  A qualified patient or a primary caregiver shall be
  4 21 granted the full legal protections provided in this section if
  4 22 the qualified patient or primary caregiver is in possession
  4 23 of a registry identification card. If a qualified patient or
  4 24 primary caregiver is arrested and is not in possession of the
  4 25 person's registry identification card, any charge or charges
  4 26 filed against the person shall be dismissed by the court if the
  4 27 person produces to the clerk of the district court, prior to
  4 28 the initial court date, a registry identification card issued
  4 29 to that person and valid at the time of the person's arrest.
  4 30    5.  A practitioner shall not be subject to arrest or
  4 31 prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any
  4 32 right or privilege for recommending the medical use of cannabis
  4 33 or for providing a written certification for the medical use of
  4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  4 35    6.  A licensed producer shall not be subject to arrest
  5  1 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial
  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,
  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    3 31    1.  A qualified patient who has been issued and who possesses
  3 32 a registry identification card shall not be subject to arrest
  3 33 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of
  3 34 any right or privilege for the medical use of cannabis if the
  3 35 quantity of cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.
  4  1    2.  A qualified patient's primary caregiver shall not be
  4  2 subject to arrest or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty,
  4  3 or the denial of any right or privilege for the medical use of
  4  4 cannabis on behalf of the qualified patient, if the quantity of
  4  5 cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.
  4  6    3.  Subsection 1 does not apply to a qualified patient under
  4  7 the age of eighteen years unless all of the following apply:
  4  8    a.  The qualified patient's practitioner has explained the
  4  9 potential risks and benefits of the medical use of cannabis
  4 10 to the qualified patient and to a parent, guardian, or person
  4 11 having legal custody of the qualified patient.
  4 12    b.  A parent, guardian, or person having legal custody agrees
  4 13 in writing to do all of the following:
  4 14    (1)  Allow the qualified patient's medical use of cannabis.
  4 15    (2)  Serve as the qualified patient's primary caregiver.
  4 16    (3)  Control the dosage and the frequency of the medical use
  4 17 of cannabis by the qualified patient.
  4 18    (4)  Designate one or more primary caregivers for the
  4 19 qualified patient.
  4 20    4.  A qualified patient or a primary caregiver shall be
  4 21 granted the full legal protections provided in this section if
  4 22 the qualified patient or primary caregiver is in possession
  4 23 of a registry identification card. If a qualified patient or
  4 24 primary caregiver is arrested and is not in possession of the
  4 25 person's registry identification card, any charge or charges
  4 26 filed against the person shall be dismissed by the court if the
  4 27 person produces to the clerk of the district court, prior to
  4 28 the initial court date, a registry identification card issued
  4 29 to that person and valid at the time of the person's arrest.
  4 30    5.  A practitioner shall not be subject to arrest or
  4 31 prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any
  4 32 right or privilege for recommending the medical use of cannabis
  4 33 or for providing a written certification for the medical use of
  4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.

  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,

  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.

  3 33 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of
  3 34 any right or privilege for the medical use of cannabis if the
  3 35 quantity of cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.

  4 14    (1)  Allow the qualified patient's medical use of cannabis.
  4 15    (2)  Serve as the qualified patient's primary caregiver.
  4 16    (3)  Control the dosage and the frequency of the medical use
  4 17 of cannabis by the qualified patient.
  4 18    (4)  Designate one or more primary caregivers for the
  4 19 qualified patient.
  4 20    4.  A qualified patient or a primary caregiver shall be
  4 21 granted the full legal protections provided in this section if
  4 22 the qualified patient or primary caregiver is in possession
  4 23 of a registry identification card. If a qualified patient or
  4 24 primary caregiver is arrested and is not in possession of the
  4 25 person's registry identification card, any charge or charges
  4 26 filed against the person shall be dismissed by the court if the
  4 27 person produces to the clerk of the district court, prior to
  4 28 the initial court date, a registry identification card issued
  4 29 to that person and valid at the time of the person's arrest.
  4 30    5.  A practitioner shall not be subject to arrest or
  4 31 prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any
  4 32 right or privilege for recommending the medical use of cannabis
  4 33 or for providing a written certification for the medical use of
  4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  4 35    6.  A licensed producer shall not be subject to arrest
  5  1 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial
  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,
  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    3 35 quantity of cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.
  4  1    2.  A qualified patient's primary caregiver shall not be
  4  2 subject to arrest or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty,
  4  3 or the denial of any right or privilege for the medical use of
  4  4 cannabis on behalf of the qualified patient, if the quantity of
  4  5 cannabis does not exceed an adequate supply.
  4  6    3.  Subsection 1 does not apply to a qualified patient under
  4  7 the age of eighteen years unless all of the following apply:
  4  8    a.  The qualified patient's practitioner has explained the
  4  9 potential risks and benefits of the medical use of cannabis
  4 10 to the qualified patient and to a parent, guardian, or person
  4 11 having legal custody of the qualified patient.
  4 12    b.  A parent, guardian, or person having legal custody agrees
  4 13 in writing to do all of the following:
  4 14    (1)  Allow the qualified patient's medical use of cannabis.
  4 15    (2)  Serve as the qualified patient's primary caregiver.
  4 16    (3)  Control the dosage and the frequency of the medical use
  4 17 of cannabis by the qualified patient.
  4 18    (4)  Designate one or more primary caregivers for the
  4 19 qualified patient.
  4 20    4.  A qualified patient or a primary caregiver shall be
  4 21 granted the full legal protections provided in this section if
  4 22 the qualified patient or primary caregiver is in possession
  4 23 of a registry identification card. If a qualified patient or
  4 24 primary caregiver is arrested and is not in possession of the
  4 25 person's registry identification card, any charge or charges
  4 26 filed against the person shall be dismissed by the court if the
  4 27 person produces to the clerk of the district court, prior to
  4 28 the initial court date, a registry identification card issued
  4 29 to that person and valid at the time of the person's arrest.
  4 30    5.  A practitioner shall not be subject to arrest or
  4 31 prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any
  4 32 right or privilege for recommending the medical use of cannabis
  4 33 or for providing a written certification for the medical use of
  4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  4 35    6.  A licensed producer shall not be subject to arrest
  5  1 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial
  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,
  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.

  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    4  8    a.  The qualified patient's practitioner has explained the
  4  9 potential risks and benefits of the medical use of cannabis
  4 10 to the qualified patient and to a parent, guardian, or person
  4 11 having legal custody of the qualified patient.
  4 12    b.  A parent, guardian, or person having legal custody agrees
  4 13 in writing to do all of the following:
  4 14    (1)  Allow the qualified patient's medical use of cannabis.
  4 15    (2)  Serve as the qualified patient's primary caregiver.
  4 16    (3)  Control the dosage and the frequency of the medical use
  4 17 of cannabis by the qualified patient.
  4 18    (4)  Designate one or more primary caregivers for the
  4 19 qualified patient.
  4 20    4.  A qualified patient or a primary caregiver shall be
  4 21 granted the full legal protections provided in this section if
  4 22 the qualified patient or primary caregiver is in possession
  4 23 of a registry identification card. If a qualified patient or
  4 24 primary caregiver is arrested and is not in possession of the
  4 25 person's registry identification card, any charge or charges
  4 26 filed against the person shall be dismissed by the court if the
  4 27 person produces to the clerk of the district court, prior to
  4 28 the initial court date, a registry identification card issued
  4 29 to that person and valid at the time of the person's arrest.
  4 30    5.  A practitioner shall not be subject to arrest or
  4 31 prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any
  4 32 right or privilege for recommending the medical use of cannabis
  4 33 or for providing a written certification for the medical use of
  4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  4 35    6.  A licensed producer shall not be subject to arrest
  5  1 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial
  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,
  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    4  9 potential risks and benefits of the medical use of cannabis

  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    4 19 qualified patient.
  4 20    4.  A qualified patient or a primary caregiver shall be
  4 21 granted the full legal protections provided in this section if
  4 22 the qualified patient or primary caregiver is in possession
  4 23 of a registry identification card. If a qualified patient or
  4 24 primary caregiver is arrested and is not in possession of the
  4 25 person's registry identification card, any charge or charges
  4 26 filed against the person shall be dismissed by the court if the
  4 27 person produces to the clerk of the district court, prior to
  4 28 the initial court date, a registry identification card issued
  4 29 to that person and valid at the time of the person's arrest.
  4 30    5.  A practitioner shall not be subject to arrest or
  4 31 prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any
  4 32 right or privilege for recommending the medical use of cannabis
  4 33 or for providing a written certification for the medical use of
  4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  4 35    6.  A licensed producer shall not be subject to arrest
  5  1 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial
  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,
  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.

  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.

  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,
  5  9 and 809A.  Any such property seized is subject to forfeiture
  5 10 as provided by chapter 809 or 809A.  Cannabis, paraphernalia,
  5 11 or other property seized from a qualified patient or primary
  5 12 caregiver in connection with the claimed medical use of
  5 13 cannabis shall be returned immediately upon the determination
  5 14 by a court that the qualified patient or primary caregiver is
  5 15 entitled to the protections of the provisions of this chapter,
  5 16 as may be evidenced by a failure to actively investigate the
  5 17 case, a decision not to prosecute, the dismissal of charges,
  5 18 or acquittal.
  5 19    8.  A person shall not be subject to arrest or prosecution,
  5 20 civil or criminal penalty, or the denial of any right or
  5 21 privilege for a cannabis=related offense simply for being in
  5 22 the presence of the medical use of cannabis as permitted under
  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    4 34 cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  4 35    6.  A licensed producer shall not be subject to arrest
  5  1 or prosecution, civil or criminal penalty, or the denial
  5  2 of any right or privilege, for the processing, production,
  5  3 possession, manufacture, distribution, dispensing, delivery, or
  5  4 transporting of cannabis pursuant to this chapter.
  5  5    7.  Any property interest that is possessed, owned, or
  5  6 used in connection with the medical use of cannabis, or acts
  5  7 incidental to such use, and any property seized shall be
  5  8 treated in accordance with the provisions of chapters 808, 809,

  5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    5 23 the provisions of this chapter.
  5 24    Sec. 6.    5 24    Sec. 6.    5 25 limitations on the medical use of cannabis ==== criminal penalties.
  5 26    1.  Participation in a medical use of cannabis program
  5 27 by a qualified patient or primary caregiver does not relieve
  5 28 the qualified patient or primary caregiver from any of the
  5 29 following:
  5 30    a.  Criminal prosecution or civil penalties for activities
  5 31 not authorized under this chapter.
  5 32    b.  Criminal prosecution or liability for damages arising
  5 33 out of the operation of a vehicle while under the influence of
  5 34 cannabis.
  5 35    c.  Criminal prosecution or civil penalties for possession or
  6  1 use of cannabis in any of the following places:
  6  2    (1)  In a school bus or public vehicle.
  6  3    (2)  On the grounds of any public or private preschool or
  6  4 elementary or secondary school.
  6  5    (3)  In the workplace of the qualified patient's or primary
  6  6 caregiver's employment.
  6  7    (4)  At a public park, recreation center, youth center, or
  6  8 other public place.
  6  9    2.  A qualified patient or primary caregiver who makes
  6 10 a fraudulent representation to a law enforcement officer
  6 11 about the person's medical use of cannabis to avoid arrest
  6 12 or prosecution for a cannabis=related offense is guilty of a
  6 13 simple misdemeanor.
  6 14    3.  A licensed producer who does any of the following shall
  6 15 be subject to arrest, prosecution, and civil or criminal
  6 16 penalties under state or federal law:
  6 17    a.  Sells, distributes, dispenses, delivers, or transfers
  6 18 cannabis to a person not approved by the department pursuant to
  6 19 this chapter.
  6 20    b.  Obtains, transports, or delivers cannabis outside this
  6 21 state in violation of federal law.
  6 22    Sec. 7.    5 26    1.  Participation in a medical use of cannabis program
  5 27 by a qualified patient or primary caregiver does not relieve
  5 28 the qualified patient or primary caregiver from any of the
  5 29 following:
  5 30    a.  Criminal prosecution or civil penalties for activities
  5 31 not authorized under this chapter.
  5 32    b.  Criminal prosecution or liability for damages arising
  5 33 out of the operation of a vehicle while under the influence of

  5 33 out of the operation of a vehicle while under the influence of
  5 34 cannabis.
  5 35    c.  Criminal prosecution or civil penalties for possession or
  6  1 use of cannabis in any of the following places:
  6  2    (1)  In a school bus or public vehicle.
  6  3    (2)  On the grounds of any public or private preschool or
  6  4 elementary or secondary school.
  6  5    (3)  In the workplace of the qualified patient's or primary
  6  6 caregiver's employment.
  6  7    (4)  At a public park, recreation center, youth center, or
  6  8 other public place.
  6  9    2.  A qualified patient or primary caregiver who makes
  6 10 a fraudulent representation to a law enforcement officer
  6 11 about the person's medical use of cannabis to avoid arrest
  6 12 or prosecution for a cannabis=related offense is guilty of a
  6 13 simple misdemeanor.
  6 14    3.  A licensed producer who does any of the following shall
  6 15 be subject to arrest, prosecution, and civil or criminal
  6 16 penalties under state or federal law:
  6 17    a.  Sells, distributes, dispenses, delivers, or transfers
  6 18 cannabis to a person not approved by the department pursuant to
  6 19 this chapter.
  6 20    b.  Obtains, transports, or delivers cannabis outside this
  6 21 state in violation of federal law.
  6 22    Sec. 7.    5 31 not authorized under this chapter.
  5 32    b.  Criminal prosecution or liability for damages arising
  5 33 out of the operation of a vehicle while under the influence of
  5 34 cannabis.
  5 35    c.  Criminal prosecution or civil penalties for possession or
  6  1 use of cannabis in any of the following places:
  6  2    (1)  In a school bus or public vehicle.
  6  3    (2)  On the grounds of any public or private preschool or
  6  4 elementary or secondary school.
  6  5    (3)  In the workplace of the qualified patient's or primary
  6  6 caregiver's employment.

  6 22    Sec. 7.    6 21 state in violation of federal law.
  6 22    Sec. 7.    6 22    Sec. 7.    6 23 ==== duties.
  6 24    1.  No later than August 15, 2016, the director of public
  6 25 health shall establish a medical cannabis advisory board
  6 26 consisting of eight practitioners representing the fields of
  6 27 neurology, pain management, medical oncology, psychiatry,
  6 28 infectious disease, family medicine, and gynecology.  The
  6 29 practitioners shall be nationally board=certified in their
  6 30 area of specialty and knowledgeable about the medical use of
  6 31 cannabis.
  6 32    2.  Advisory board members shall be chosen for appointment by
  6 33 the director from a list proposed by the Iowa medical society.
  6 34    3.  A quorum of the advisory board shall consist of five
  6 35 members.
  7  1    4.  The advisory board shall have the following duties:
  7  2    a.  Review and recommend to the department for approval
  7  3 additional debilitating medical conditions for persons who
  7  4 would benefit from the medical use of cannabis.
  7  5    b.  Accept and review petitions to add medical conditions,
  7  6 medical treatments, or diseases to the list of debilitating
  7  7 medical conditions that qualify for the medical use of
  7  8 cannabis.
  7  9    c.  Convene at least twice per year to conduct public
  7 10 hearings and to evaluate petitions, which shall be maintained
  7 11 as confidential personal health information, to add medical
  7 12 conditions, medical treatments, or diseases to the list of
  7 13 debilitating medical conditions that qualify for the medical
  7 14 use of cannabis.
  7 15    d.  Issue recommendations concerning rules to be adopted for
  7 16 the issuance of registry identification cards.
  7 17    e.  Recommend quantities of cannabis that are necessary
  7 18 to constitute an adequate supply for qualified patients and
  7 19 primary caregivers.
  7 20    f.  Review actions of the department in approving or denying
  7 21 registry identification card applications to ensure such
  7 22 approvals and denials are issued pursuant to the requirements
  7 23 of section 124E.8. In reviewing such actions, the advisory
  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions
  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    6 24    1.  No later than August 15, 2016, the director of public
  6 25 health shall establish a medical cannabis advisory board
  6 26 consisting of eight practitioners representing the fields of
  6 27 neurology, pain management, medical oncology, psychiatry,
  6 28 infectious disease, family medicine, and gynecology.  The
  6 29 practitioners shall be nationally board=certified in their
  6 30 area of specialty and knowledgeable about the medical use of
  6 31 cannabis.
  6 32    2.  Advisory board members shall be chosen for appointment by
  6 33 the director from a list proposed by the Iowa medical society.
  6 34    3.  A quorum of the advisory board shall consist of five
  6 35 members.

  7  2    a.  Review and recommend to the department for approval

  7 14 use of cannabis.

  7 16 the issuance of registry identification cards.

  7 18 to constitute an adequate supply for qualified patients and
  7 19 primary caregivers.
  7 20    f.  Review actions of the department in approving or denying
  7 21 registry identification card applications to ensure such
  7 22 approvals and denials are issued pursuant to the requirements
  7 23 of section 124E.8. In reviewing such actions, the advisory
  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions
  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".

  7 20    f.  Review actions of the department in approving or denying
  7 21 registry identification card applications to ensure such
  7 22 approvals and denials are issued pursuant to the requirements
  7 23 of section 124E.8. In reviewing such actions, the advisory
  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions
  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    6 27 neurology, pain management, medical oncology, psychiatry,
  6 28 infectious disease, family medicine, and gynecology.  The
  6 29 practitioners shall be nationally board=certified in their
  6 30 area of specialty and knowledgeable about the medical use of
  6 31 cannabis.
  6 32    2.  Advisory board members shall be chosen for appointment by
  6 33 the director from a list proposed by the Iowa medical society.
  6 34    3.  A quorum of the advisory board shall consist of five
  6 35 members.
  7  1    4.  The advisory board shall have the following duties:
  7  2    a.  Review and recommend to the department for approval
  7  3 additional debilitating medical conditions for persons who
  7  4 would benefit from the medical use of cannabis.
  7  5    b.  Accept and review petitions to add medical conditions,
  7  6 medical treatments, or diseases to the list of debilitating
  7  7 medical conditions that qualify for the medical use of
  7  8 cannabis.
  7  9    c.  Convene at least twice per year to conduct public
  7 10 hearings and to evaluate petitions, which shall be maintained
  7 11 as confidential personal health information, to add medical
  7 12 conditions, medical treatments, or diseases to the list of
  7 13 debilitating medical conditions that qualify for the medical
  7 14 use of cannabis.
  7 15    d.  Issue recommendations concerning rules to be adopted for
  7 16 the issuance of registry identification cards.
  7 17    e.  Recommend quantities of cannabis that are necessary
  7 18 to constitute an adequate supply for qualified patients and
  7 19 primary caregivers.
  7 20    f.  Review actions of the department in approving or denying
  7 21 registry identification card applications to ensure such
  7 22 approvals and denials are issued pursuant to the requirements
  7 23 of section 124E.8. In reviewing such actions, the advisory
  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions
  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    6 28 infectious disease, family medicine, and gynecology.  The

  7 20    f.  Review actions of the department in approving or denying
  7 21 registry identification card applications to ensure such
  7 22 approvals and denials are issued pursuant to the requirements
  7 23 of section 124E.8. In reviewing such actions, the advisory
  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions
  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    7 14 use of cannabis.
  7 15    d.  Issue recommendations concerning rules to be adopted for
  7 16 the issuance of registry identification cards.
  7 17    e.  Recommend quantities of cannabis that are necessary
  7 18 to constitute an adequate supply for qualified patients and
  7 19 primary caregivers.
  7 20    f.  Review actions of the department in approving or denying
  7 21 registry identification card applications to ensure such
  7 22 approvals and denials are issued pursuant to the requirements
  7 23 of section 124E.8. In reviewing such actions, the advisory
  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions
  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    7 15    d.  Issue recommendations concerning rules to be adopted for
  7 16 the issuance of registry identification cards.

  7 19 primary caregivers.

  7 24 board shall be subject to the same confidentiality restrictions

  7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    7 25 imposed on the department pursuant to section 124E.7,
  7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    7 26 subsection 2, paragraph "a".
  7 27    Sec. 8.    7 27    Sec. 8.    7 28    1.  No later than October 1, 2016, and after consultation
  7 29 with the medical cannabis advisory board, the department shall
  7 30 adopt rules pursuant to chapter 17A to establish and implement
  7 31 a medical use of cannabis program consistent with the purposes
  7 32 of this chapter.  The department may adopt emergency rules
  7 33 pursuant to chapter 17A to implement this section and the rules
  7 34 shall be effective immediately upon filing unless a later date
  7 35 is specified in the rules.  The rules shall do all of the
  8  1 following:
  8  2    a.  Govern the manner in which the department shall consider
  8  3 applications for new and renewal registry identification cards
  8  4 and for qualified patients and primary caregivers.
  8  5    b.  Define the amount of cannabis that constitutes an
  8  6 adequate supply, including amounts for topical treatments.
  8  7    c.  Identify criteria and set forth procedures for including
  8  8 additional medical conditions, medical treatments, or diseases
  8  9 on the list of debilitating medical conditions that qualify
  8 10 for the medical use of cannabis.  Procedures shall include a
  8 11 petition process and shall allow for public comment and public
  8 12 hearings before the advisory board.
  8 13    d.  Set forth additional medical conditions, medical
  8 14 treatments, or diseases for inclusion on the list of
  8 15 debilitating medical conditions that qualify for the medical
  8 16 use of cannabis as recommended by the advisory board.
  8 17    e.  Establish requirements for the licensure of producers and
  8 18 set forth procedures to obtain licenses.
  8 19    f.  Develop a distribution system for cannabis within
  8 20 this state under this chapter that provides for all of the
  8 21 following:
  8 22    (1)  Cannabis production facilities within this state housed
  8 23 on secured grounds and operated by licensed producers.
  8 24    (2)  The distribution of cannabis to qualified patients
  8 25 and their primary caregivers under this chapter at locations
  8 26 designated by the department.
  8 27    g.  Establish application and renewal fees that generate
  8 28 revenues sufficient to offset all expenses of implementing and
  8 29 administering this chapter.
  8 30    h.  Specify and implement procedures that address public
  8 31 safety including security procedures and product quality,
  8 32 safety, and labeling.
  8 33    2.  The department shall do all of the following:
  8 34    a.  Maintain a confidential file containing the names
  8 35 and addresses of the persons who have either applied for or
  9  1 received a registry identification card. Individual names
  9  2 contained in the file shall be confidential and shall not be
  9  3 subject to disclosure, except as provided in subparagraph (1).
  9  4    (1)  Information in the confidential file maintained
  9  5 pursuant to this paragraph "a" may be released to the following
  9  6 persons under the following circumstances:
  9  7    (a)  To authorized employees or agents of the department as
  9  8 necessary to perform the duties of the department pursuant to
  9  9 this chapter.
  9 10    (b)  To authorized employees of state or local law
  9 11 enforcement agencies, but only for the purpose of verifying
  9 12 that a person is lawfully in possession of a registry
  9 13 identification card issued pursuant to this chapter.
  9 14    (2)  Release of information pursuant to subparagraph
  9 15 (1) shall be consistent with the federal Health Insurance
  9 16 Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, Pub. L. No.
  9 17 104=191.
  9 18    b.  Submit an annual report to the general assembly by
  9 19 January 15 of each year that does not disclose any identifying
  9 20 information about registry identification cardholders or
  9 21 practitioners, but does contain, at a minimum, all of the
  9 22 following information:
  9 23    (1)  The number of applications and renewal applications
  9 24 submitted for registry identification cards.
  9 25    (2)  The number of registered qualified patients and
  9 26 registered primary caregivers in each county.
  9 27    (3)  The nature of the debilitating medical conditions of the
  9 28 qualified patients.
  9 29    (4)  The number of registry identification cards revoked.
  9 30    (5)  The number of practitioners providing written
  9 31 certifications for qualified patients.
  9 32    (6)  The sufficiency of the overall supply of cannabis
  9 33 available to qualified patients statewide.
  9 34    Sec. 9.    7 29 with the medical cannabis advisory board, the department shall
  7 30 adopt rules pursuant to chapter 17A to establish and implement
  7 31 a medical use of cannabis program consistent with the purposes
  7 32 of this chapter.  The department may adopt emergency rules
  7 33 pursuant to chapter 17A to implement this section and the rules
  7 34 shall be effective immediately upon filing unless a later date
  7 35 is specified in the rules.  The rules shall do all of the
  8  1 following:

  8 12 hearings before the advisory board.
  8 13    d.  Set forth additional medical conditions, medical
  8 14 treatments, or diseases for inclusion on the list of
  8 15 debilitating medical conditions that qualify for the medical
  8 16 use of cannabis as recommended by the advisory board.
  8 17    e.  Establish requirements for the licensure of producers and
  8 18 set forth procedures to obtain licenses.

  8 29 administering this chapter.

  8 31 safety including security procedures and product quality,
  8 32 safety, and labeling.

  9 24 submitted for registry identification cards.
  9 25    (2)  The number of registered qualified patients and
  9 26 registered primary caregivers in each county.
  9 27    (3)  The nature of the debilitating medical conditions of the
  9 28 qualified patients.
  9 29    (4)  The number of registry identification cards revoked.
  9 30    (5)  The number of practitioners providing written
  9 31 certifications for qualified patients.
  9 32    (6)  The sufficiency of the overall supply of cannabis
  9 33 available to qualified patients statewide.
  9 34    Sec. 9.    7 34 shall be effective immediately upon filing unless a later date
  7 35 is specified in the rules.  The rules shall do all of the
  8  1 following:
  8  2    a.  Govern the manner in which the department shall consider
  8  3 applications for new and renewal registry identification cards
  8  4 and for qualified patients and primary caregivers.
  8  5    b.  Define the amount of cannabis that constitutes an
  8  6 adequate supply, including amounts for topical treatments.
  8  7    c.  Identify criteria and set forth procedures for including
  8  8 additional medical conditions, medical treatments, or diseases
  8  9 on the list of debilitating medical conditions that qualify
  8 10 for the medical use of cannabis.  Procedures shall include a
  8 11 petition process and shall allow for public comment and public
  8 12 hearings before the advisory board.
  8 13    d.  Set forth additional medical conditions, medical
  8 14 treatments, or diseases for inclusion on the list of
  8 15 debilitating medical conditions that qualify for the medical
  8 16 use of cannabis as recommended by the advisory board.
  8 17    e.  Establish requirements for the licensure of producers and
  8 18 set forth procedures to obtain licenses.
  8 19    f.  Develop a distribution system for cannabis within
  8 20 this state under this chapter that provides for all of the
  8 21 following:
  8 22    (1)  Cannabis production facilities within this state housed
  8 23 on secured grounds and operated by licensed producers.
  8 24    (2)  The distribution of cannabis to qualified patients
  8 25 and their primary caregivers under this chapter at locations
  8 26 designated by the department.
  8 27    g.  Establish application and renewal fees that generate
  8 28 revenues sufficient to offset all expenses of implementing and
  8 29 administering this chapter.
  8 30    h.  Specify and implement procedures that address public
  8 31 safety including security procedures and product quality,
  8 32 safety, and labeling.
  8 33    2.  The department shall do all of the following:
  8 34    a.  Maintain a confidential file containing the names
  8 35 and addresses of the persons who have either applied for or
  9  1 received a registry identification card. Individual names
  9  2 contained in the file shall be confidential and shall not be
  9  3 subject to disclosure, except as provided in subparagraph (1).
  9  4    (1)  Information in the confidential file maintained
  9  5 pursuant to this paragraph "a" may be released to the following
  9  6 persons under the following circumstances:
  9  7    (a)  To authorized employees or agents of the department as
  9  8 necessary to perform the duties of the department pursuant to
  9  9 this chapter.
  9 10    (b)  To authorized employees of state or local law
  9 11 enforcement agencies, but only for the purpose of verifying
  9 12 that a person is lawfully in possession of a registry
  9 13 identification card issued pursuant to this chapter.
  9 14    (2)  Release of information pursuant to subparagraph
  9 15 (1) shall be consistent with the federal Health Insurance
  9 16 Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, Pub. L. No.
  9 17 104=191.
  9 18    b.  Submit an annual report to the general assembly by
  9 19 January 15 of each year that does not disclose any identifying
  9 20 information about registry identification cardholders or
  9 21 practitioners, but does contain, at a minimum, all of the
  9 22 following information:
  9 23    (1)  The number of applications and renewal applications
  9 24 submitted for registry identification cards.
  9 25    (2)  The number of registered qualified patients and
  9 26 registered primary caregivers in each county.
  9 27    (3)  The nature of the debilitating medical conditions of the
  9 28 qualified patients.
  9 29    (4)  The number of registry identification cards revoked.
  9 30    (5)  The number of practitioners providing written
  9 31 certifications for qualified patients.
  9 32    (6)  The sufficiency of the overall supply of cannabis
  9 33 available to qualified patients statewide.
